fields.name: Mount Kilimanjaro
fields.description: Mount Kilimanjaro is Africa's highest peak and the world's tallest free-standing mountain at 5,895 metres (19,341 ft). Located in Kilimanjaro National Park — a UNESCO World Heritage Site — it presents three volcanic cones: Kibo, Mawenzi, and Shira. Kilimanjaro is a bucket-list trekking destination offering five main routes (Machame, Marangu, Lemosho, Rongai, Umbwe), each with unique scenery through five distinct ecological zones: cultivated farmland, montane forest, heath and moorland, alpine desert, and the arctic summit. The iconic snow-capped summit, Uhuru Peak, can be reached by non-technical climbers with proper acclimatisation. Over 50,000 climbers attempt the summit each year.
fields.short_description: Africa's highest peak and world's tallest free-standing mountain at 5,895m — a bucket-list trekking destination with five climbing routes.
fields.access_info: Fly into Kilimanjaro International Airport (JRO) or Arusha Airport. Transfer to Moshi town (~45 mins from JRO). The Marangu Gate is about 95km and 1.5 hours from Moshi. Most routes start from various gates around the mountain. A licensed guide is mandatory and must be hired through a registered operator.
fields.seasonal_availability: The mountain can be climbed year-round but is best during the two dry seasons: January–March and June–October. The short rainy season runs November–December and the long rains March–May. July and August are the busiest and clearest months.

fields.name: Serengeti National Park
fields.description: Serengeti National Park is Tanzania's oldest and most famous national park, covering approximately 14,763 km². It is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and a Biosphere Reserve, internationally renowned for the Great Wildebeest Migration — the largest animal migration on Earth — where over 1.5 million wildebeest, 250,000 zebra, and 500,000 gazelle move in a continuous clockwise circuit across the Serengeti–Mara ecosystem. The park hosts Africa's Big Five (lion, leopard, elephant, buffalo, rhinoceros) and over 500 bird species. The iconic Seronera Valley is famous for year-round lion and leopard sightings. Balloon safaris at sunrise offer a breathtaking aerial perspective of the endless plains.
fields.short_description: Home of the Great Migration — 1.5 million wildebeest crossing the endless plains. Africa's most iconic safari destination with the Big Five.
fields.access_info: Access via Arusha (~335km, 5–6 hours drive) through the Naabi Hill Gate, or fly into Seronera Airstrip or Grumeti Airstrip directly from Arusha or Nairobi. Road access from the Ngorongoro Conservation Area is also popular for combined safari itineraries.
fields.seasonal_availability: Open year-round. The Great Migration river crossings at the Mara River occur July–October. Calving season (January–February) in the southern Serengeti offers dramatic wildlife spectacles. The short rain season (November–December) brings lush green landscapes.

fields.name: Ngorongoro Crater
fields.description: The Ngorongoro Crater is the world's largest intact volcanic caldera and a UNESCO World Heritage Site within the Ngorongoro Conservation Area. Formed 2–3 million years ago when a massive volcano collapsed inward, the crater is approximately 19km wide and 600 metres deep, covering 304 km². It forms a near-perfect natural enclosure supporting one of Africa's densest wildlife populations — including approximately 30,000 large animals: the Big Five, flamingos on Lake Magadi, wildebeest, zebra, and one of the highest densities of lions in Africa. The crater also shelters one of the few remaining black rhino populations in Tanzania. The Ngorongoro Conservation Area uniquely blends wildlife conservation with Maasai pastoral communities living alongside the wildlife.
fields.short_description: World's largest intact volcanic caldera — a natural wildlife paradise sheltering 30,000 animals including Africa's densest lion population and rare black rhinos.
fields.access_info: Located 180km west of Arusha via the Arusha–Dodoma highway. The Lodoare Gate is the main entrance. Access by 4WD vehicle only inside the crater — guides recommended. Can be combined with Serengeti and Lake Manyara for the northern safari circuit.
fields.best_time_to_visit: June–October (dry season) for best wildlife visibility
fields.seasonal_availability: Open year-round. Wildlife is visible throughout the year due to the crater's enclosed ecosystem. Dry season (June–October) offers better road conditions and animal concentrations around water sources. Wet season (March–May) features lush scenery and fewer tourists.

fields.name: Zanzibar Stone Town
fields.description: Zanzibar Stone Town is the old city and cultural heart of Zanzibar City, the capital of the Zanzibar Archipelago. It is a UNESCO World Heritage Site, recognised for its outstanding Swahili architecture — a unique blend of Arab, Persian, Indian, and European influences accumulated over centuries of Indian Ocean trade. Key landmarks include the House of Wonders (Beit el-Ajaib), the Old Fort (Ngome Kongwe), the Palace Museum (Beit el-Sahel), and the Anglican Cathedral built over the site of the last open slave market in Africa. The labyrinthine streets are filled with hand-carved Zanzibari wooden doors, colourful coral-stone houses, bustling bazaars, and aromatic spice markets. The waterfront Forodhani Gardens come alive at sunset with the famous street food night market.
fields.short_description: UNESCO World Heritage city blending Swahili, Arab, Indian and colonial heritage — famous for carved wooden doors, spice markets, and the history of the East African slave trade.
fields.access_info: Fly into Zanzibar Abeid Amani Karume International Airport (ZNZ), 6km south of Stone Town, with direct connections to Dar es Salaam, Nairobi, and international destinations. Alternatively, take the Azam Marine or Kilimanjaro Fast Ferry from Dar es Salaam port (~2 hours). Stone Town itself is best explored on foot.
fields.best_time_to_visit: June–October (long dry season) and December–February (short dry season)
fields.seasonal_availability: Stone Town can be visited year-round. The best beach conditions and sea visibility for diving/snorkelling are during the dry seasons (June–October and December–February). The long rain season (March–May) brings heavy downpours but is quieter and cheaper.
